stem: A 32-year-old client with bipolar disorder is admitted after their sertraline (SSRI) dose was doubled while taking lithium. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two actions the nurse should take, and two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content: Situation: 32-year-old client with bipolar disorder experiencing acute central nervous system (CNS) irritability and autonomic instability. Background: The client has been stable on lithium. Sertraline dosage recently increased to 200mg daily. Assessment: At 14:30, the client presents with diaphoresis, agitation, and uncontrollable leg jerking (clonus). Vital signs include a blood pressure of 182/104 mmHg, heart rate of 132 bpm, respiratory rate of 24 breaths/min, and a temperature of 103.2°F (39.6°C). Recommendation: Immediately discontinue all serotonergic agents. Administer IV benzodiazepines to manage agitation and hyperthermia. Monitor vital signs and neurological status closely.

tabs.content: BP 182/104 mmHg, HR 132 bpm, RR 24 breaths/min, T 103.2°F (39.6°C). Client is shivering.

actionOptions.text: Administer IV benzodiazepines (e.g., diazepam) to control rigidity.
Instruct the client to perform muscle exercises to stop the clonus.
Administer STAT PO lithium to calm the patient down.

parameterOptions.text: Core temperature and presence of inducible clonus.
Neurological status and heart rate (autonomic stability).
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose.
Presence of a positive Babinski sign.

rationale.correct: The client is most likely experiencing serotonin syndrome (c2). Lithium potentiates serotonin, and when combined with a high-dose SSRI (sertraline), it can trigger a life-threatening autonomic crisis. Key signs are hyperreflexia, clonus, hyperthermia (103.2°F/39.6°C), and mydriasis. Priority actions include stopping the serotonergic drugs (a1) to prevent further serotonin accumulation and administering benzodiazepines (a2) to reduce body temperature and muscle rigidity. Monitoring should focus on core temperature and presence of inducible clonus (p1) to assess the effectiveness of cooling measures and autonomic stability (p2) to detect any cardiovascular compromise.
clinicalPearls: Serotonin syndrome is characterized by hyperreflexia and clonus (involuntary, rhythmic muscle contractions), especially in the lower extremities.
Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS) presents similarly but features 'lead-pipe' rigidity (generalized muscular rigidity without clonus) and is typically associated with antipsychotic medications.
Cyproheptadine is the specific antidote for serotonin syndrome if benzodiazepines and supportive measures are ineffective.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking this is solely lithium toxicity based on the serum level.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While the lithium level is high-therapeutic (1.4 mEq/L), the patient's fever, jerking legs (clonus), and autonomic instability are disproportionate to lithium toxicity alone and strongly indicate a drug interaction. Consider the recent SSRI dose increase as the primary trigger.

mnemonic.title: S-H-I-V-E-R
mnemonic.expansion: S-Sweating, H-Hyperreflexia/Clonus, I-Increased Temperature, V-Vital Sign Instability, E-Encephalopathy, R-Restlessness
